{{Infobox scientist | name = Robert V. Hogg | image = | image_size = | alt = Bob Hogg | caption = | birth_date = 8 November 1924 | birth_place = [[Hannibal, Missouri]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2014|12|23|1924|11|8|df=y}} | death_place = [[Highlands Ranch, Colorado]] | residence = [[Highlands Ranch, Colorado]] | citizenship = [[United States of America]] | children= four, including [[Rob Hogg]]http://www.robhogg.org/about | nationality = American | fields = [[Statistics]] | workplaces = [[University of Iowa]] | alma_mater = [[University of Iowa]] (Ph.D.)
[[University of Illinois]] | doctoral_advisor = Allen Thornton Craig | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = eponymous textbooks ("Hogg & Craig" and "Hogg and Tanis")
[[Statistics education]]
[[Robust statistics|Robust]] and [[nonparametric statistics]]
[[Stigler's law of eponymy|Early version of]] [[Basu's theorem]] | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = [[Gottfried E. Noether|Gottfried Noether]] Award 2001 ([[Nonparametric statistics|nonparametrics]])
[[President of the American Statistical Association|President]] of [[American Statistical Association]] 1988
Founder's Award of the [[American Statistical Association]] 1991
Fellow of the [[Institute of Mathematical Statistics]]
Carver Medal of the [[Institute of Mathematical Statistics]]
Elected Member of the [[International Statistical Institute]]
Distinguished Teaching Award of the [[Mathematical Association of America]] | signature = | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} '''Robert Vincent ("Bob") Hogg''' (8 November 1924 – 23 December 2014)[http://www.press-citizen.com/story/news/local/2014/12/24/robert-hogg/20876423/ Colleagues, family remember a statistical giant] was an [[United States|American]] [[statistician]] and professor of statistics of the [[University of Iowa]]. Hogg is known for his widely used textbooks on [[statistics]] (with his 1963 Ph.D. student Elliot Alan Tanis) and on [[mathematical statistics]] (with his 1950 Ph.D. advisor Allen Thornton Craig). Hogg has received recognition for his research on [[robust statistics|robust]] and [[sequential analysis|adaptive]] [[nonparametric statistics]] and for his [[scholarship]] on [[total quality management]] and [[statistics education]].{{cite journal|journal=Statistical Science|year=2007|volume=22|issue=1|pages=137–152 | doi=10.1214/088342306000000637 | title=A Conversation with Robert V. Hogg|first=Ronald Herman|last=Randles |arxiv=0708.3974}} ==Academic career== ===Early life=== Born on 8 November 1924 in [[Hannibal, Missouri]], Hogg served three years in the [[US Navy]] from 1943 through 1946. In 1947, he graduated from the [[University of Illinois]] with a bachelor's degree in mathematics. With the goal of becoming an [[actuary]], Hogg matriculated at the mathematics department of the [[University of Iowa]] (then the "[[State University of Iowa]]").Pages 137–139 in Randles. However, Hogg studied statistics under Allen Craig, who became his mentor and helped him obtain a job teaching statistics at the Mathematics Department. Hogg earned his Ph.D. 1950 under Allen Craig. After graduating, Hogg remained at the Mathematics Department, where he remained to become a long-serving professor. ===Basu's theorem: Special cases=== Hogg independently discovered a special case of "[[Basu's theorem]]", a few years [[Stigler's law of eponymy|before]] the publication by [[Deb Basu]].[[Basu's theorem]] appears in {{cite journal |last=Basu |first=D. |authorlink=Debabrata Basu |title=On Statistics Independent of a Complete Sufficient Statistic |journal= [[Sankhya (journal)|Sankhyā]] |volume=15 |issue=4 |year=1955 |pages=377–380 |mr=74745 | zbl = 0068.13401 | jstor = 25048259 |doi=10.1007/978-1-4419-5825-9_14}}{{Cite journal |doi=10.2307/2685927 |last=Boos |first=Dennis D.|author2=Oliver, Jacqueline M. Hughes |date=Aug 1998|title=Applications of Basu's Theorem |journal=[[The American Statistician]] |volume=52 |issue=3 |pages=218–221 |publisher=[[American Statistical Association]] |location=Boston |mr=1650407 | jstor = 2685927 }}For Hogg's independent and early (1953) discovery of special cases of [[Basu's theorem]], see page 511 in {{cite journal|title=Basu's Theorem with Applications: A Personalistic Review| first=Malay|last=Ghosh | journal=Sankhyā: the Indian Journal of Statistics, Series A|volume=64|date=October 2002|pages=509–531| mr=1985397 | jstor = 25051412|issue=3 }} Hogg's second paper on the topic of Basu's theorem was never published, because of a negative report by an anonymous referee in 1953.Randles and Calvin, page 2476. (Later, in his interview with Randles, Hogg speculates that the anonymous referee was [[Erich Leo Lehmann]].) Later, Basu refers "to Hogg and Craig (1956) for several interesting uses [of [[Basu's theorem]]] in proving results in distribution theory".Page 348 in ''Statistical Information and Likelihood : A Collection of Critical Essays by Dr. D. Basu'' ; [[Jayanta Kumar Ghosh|J. K. Ghosh]], editor. Springer 1988. ===Collaboration and friendship with Allen Craig=== The textbook "Hogg and Craig" was innovative, particularly in emphasizing [[sufficient statistic]]s: Sufficient statistics were treated not only for [[exponential family|parametric families]] but also for nonparametric probability distributions: In particular, the sufficiency and [[completeness (statistics)|completeness]] of the [[order statistics]] from a [[absolute continuity|continuous]] [[probability distribution|distribution]] were treated. Another innovation was the systematic derivation of the distributions of functions of several random variables by using the [[Change of variable#Application in probability|change-of-variable]] method.Page 2468 in Randles and Calvin. (Pages 139–140 in Randles.) As noted before, Craig was Hogg's mentor, helping him to obtain a teaching position while a graduate student and also supervising his thesis. Later, after Hogg had graduated, Craig became a close friend, and served as the [[best man]] at Hogg's wedding and later as the "[[godparent]]" to each of Hogg's four children. Indeed, Hogg's son Allen was [[namesake|named]] after Craig.Page 141 in Randles, which mentions only two children. Page 149 mentions four children. ===Chairing a new Department of Statistics=== In 1965 Hogg became the founding chair of the new Department of Statistics and Actuarial Science, and he remained as the chair for nineteen years. At Iowa, Hogg held other positions, including Chair of the Quality Management and Productivity Program and the Hanson Chair of Manufacturing Productivity. After serving 51 years as an instructor at the University of Iowa, Hogg became Professor Emeritus in 2001. ==Statistics education== Hogg has been a leader in [[statistics education]] in the US.Randles and Calvin, page 2468. Randles declares that Hogg is a leader in [[statistics education]] on page 144 of Randles. Hogg has received a number of educational awards by state and national organizations: these awards include the Iowa Governor’s Science Medal for Teaching in 1990, the [[Board of Regents, State of Iowa|Iowa Board of Regents']] Award for Faculty Excellence in 1992, and the Iowa Section of the [[Mathematical Association of America]] (MAA)'s Distinguished Teaching Award in 1992 with the national MAA's Distinguished Teaching Award in 1993.Randles and Calvin report that the MAA award was in 1992 (Page 2468). (Randles reports the MAA prize in 1993 on page 146.) At the University of Iowa, Hogg won his first teaching award after a student submitted a nomination with the title "There is a hog in my statistics book!".Hogg quoted on page 146 in Randles. ==Honors== Hogg's 70th birthday was marked by a conference organized by the [[Institute of Mathematical Statistics]], whose proceedings were published as a [[festschrift|special issue]] of ''Communications in Statistics — Theory and Methods'' in 1996; in the conference proceedings, a list of Hogg's publications appears on pages 2467–2481.{{cite journal | doi=10.1080/03610929608831849 | editor=James A. Calvin | title=Preface the institute of mathematical statistics central regional meeting | journal=Communications in Statistics — Theory and Methods | volume=25 | year=1996 | pages=i–viii+2459–2873 | mr=1424730 | issue=11 }}{{cite journal | first1=Ronald H.|last1=Randles | first2=James A. | last2=Calvin | journal=Communications in Statistics — Theory and Methods | volume=25 | year=1996 | title=The professional contributions of Robert V. Hogg | pages=2467–2481 | mr=1424730 | doi=10.1080/03610929608831850 | issue=11 }}{{cite journal | first=James A. | last=Calvin | journal=Communications in Statistics — Theory and Methods | volume=25 | last2=Calvin | year=1996 | first2=James A. | title=Preface | pages=2459–2465 | mr=1424730 | doi=10.1080/03610929608831849 | issue=11 }} For his research in [[nonparametric statistics]], Hogg received the [[Gottfried E. Noether|Gottfried Noether]] Senior Scholar Award in 2001. Hogg has been recognized internationally as a leading researcher in statistics and as an exemplary professor of statistics who has served as a public spokesperson for the profession. Hogg has had a particularly visible role in the United States, where he was elected as President of the [[American Statistical Association]] (ASA), serving in 1988. One of the ASA President's tasks is to arrange an annual meeting, and Hogg's diligence was rewarded by the ASA staff, who presented him with the name tag, "[[Boss Hogg]]" (after the name of a character in the television series ''[[The Dukes of Hazzard]]'').Page 147 in Randles. Three years after Hogg had served as President, he was awarded the ASA’s Founder’s Award in 1991.Page 146 in Randles. Hogg has also been internationally active on behalf of the statistics profession. Hogg is a Fellow of the [[Institute of Mathematical Statistics]], which awarded him its [[Harry C. Carver|Carver]] Medal.Page 151 in Randles. Hogg is also an Elected Member of the [[International Statistical Institute]]. ==References== ===Textbooks=== * {{Cite book | last1=Hogg | first1=Robert V. | last2=McKean | first2=Joseph W. | last3=Craig | first3=Allen T. | title=Introduction to mathematical statistics | edition=fifth | publisher=Prentice Hall | url=http://www.pearsonhighered.com/educator/product/Introduction-to-Mathematical-Statistics/9780130085078.page | location=Upper Saddle River, New Jersey | year=2005 | pages=692 | isbn=978-0-13-008507-8|mr=467974}} ("Hogg and Craig" was first published in 1959.) * {{Cite book | last1=Hogg | first1=Robert V.| last2=Tanis | first2=Elliot A.| title=Probability and Statistical Inference | edition=eight| publisher=Prentice Hall | url=http://www.pearsonhighered.com/educator/product/Probability-and-Statistical-Inference-8E/9780321584755.page | location=Upper Saddle River, New Jersey | year=2010| pages=648 | isbn=978-0-321-58475-5 }} | mr = 426223 * Hogg, Robert V., Klugman, Stuart A. ''Loss distributions.'' With the assistance of Charles C. Hewitt and Gary Patrik. Wiley Series in Probability and Mathematical Statistics: Applied Probability and Statistics. John Wiley & Sons, Inc., New York, 1984. x+235 pp. {{ISBN|0-471-87929-0}}. {{MR|747141}} * Hogg, Robert V. and Ledolter, J. (1992). ''Applied Statistics for Engineers and Physical Scientists''. Macmillan, New York. ===Articles=== * {{cite journal | last1 = Hogg | first1 = R. V. | year = 1953 | title = Testing the equality of means of rectangular populations. (Abstract) | url = | journal = Annals of Mathematical Statistics | volume = 24 | issue = | page = 691 }} * {{cite journal | last1 = Hogg | first1 = R. V. | year = 1956 | title = On the distribution of the likelihood ratio | url = | journal = Annals of Mathematical Statistics | volume = 27 | issue = | page = 529 | doi=10.1214/aoms/1177728276}} *{{cite journal | mr=86456 | last1=Hogg|first1=Robert V.|last2=Craig|first2=Allen T.|title=Sufficient statistics in elementary distribution theory|journal=Sankhyā |volume=17 | issue=3|year=1956|pages=209–216 | jstor=25048308}} * {{Cite journal | doi = 10.2307/2286160 | issn = 0162-1459 | volume = 69 | issue = 348 | pages = 909 | last = Hogg | first = Robert V. | title = Adaptive Robust Procedures: A Partial Review and Some Suggestions for Future Applications and Theory | journal = Journal of the American Statistical Association | year = 1974 | url = https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/2286160?uid=3739560&uid=2&uid=4&uid=3739256&sid=21102255315677 | jstor= 2286160}} ====Statistics education and the statistics profession==== * Robert V. Hogg (1978). An introduction to mathematical statistics. In ''Studies in Statistics'' (Robert V. Hogg, ed.) 1–7. [[Mathematical Association of America]] (Washington) * Robert V. Hogg (Ed) (1980). Modern statistics: Methods and applications. Arner. Math. Soc. (Providence) * Robert V. Hogg (1982). On graduate programs in statistics. In Teach. Statist. and Statist. Consult. (J.S. Rustagi and D.A. Wolfe, ed.) 71–80. Academic (New York) * Robert V. Hogg and Jim Swift (1982). Statistical education at the school level in the United States and Canada. In Teaching Statistics in Schools Throughout the World (Vic Barnett, ed.) 139–171. Internat. Statist. Inst. (Voorburg, Netherlands) * {{cite journal | last1 = Hogg | first1 = Robert V. | year = 1988 | title = Comments on Harold Hotelling's views on teaching statistics | url = | journal = Statist. Sci. | volume = 3 | issue = | pages = 95–97 }} * Robert V. Hogg (1989). On statistical education in the United States since 1920. In ASA Sesquicentennial Invited Paper Sessions (Mitchell Gail and Norman L. Johnson, eds.) 286–292. Amer. Statist. Assoc. (Alexandria, VA) * {{cite journal|doi=10.2307/2289836|first=Robert V. |last=Hogg | title=How to Hope with Statistics (ASA Presidential Address)| journal=Journal of the American Statistical Association|volume=84|issue=405|date=March 1989|pages=1–5 | jstor=2289836|authorlink=Robert V. Hogg}} | jstor = 2289836 * {{cite journal |jstor=2684473 |pages=342–343 |last1=Hogg |first1=R. V. |title=Statistical Education: Improvements Are Badly Needed |volume=45 |issue=4 |journal=The American Statistician |year=1991 |doi=10.2307/2684473}} * {{Cite book | title=Best Practices in Introductory Statistics (Draft 2000.06.09) | editor=First Courses in Statistical Science Working Group | first1=Joan |last1=Garfield|first2=Bob|last2=Hogg | first3=Candace | last3=Schau | first4=Dex | last4=Whittinghill | publisher=[[American Statistical Association]] | series=Undergraduate Statistics Education Initiative Position Paper |date=9 June 2000| url=http://www.amstat.org/education/pdfs/usei_1st.pdf | issue=2000.06.09 |authorlink2=Robert V. Hogg}} * {{cite journal | last1 = Hogg | first1 = Robert V. | last2 = Hogg | first2 = Mary C. | year = 1995 | title = Continuous Quality Improvement in Higher Education | url = | journal = International Statistical Review / Revue Internationale de Statistique | volume = 63 | issue = 1| pages = 35–48 | doi=10.2307/1403776}} ==External links== * [http://www.stat.uiowa.edu/~bhogg/ Hogg's homepage at the University of Iowa] * [http://www.stat.uiowa.edu/people/history-by-hogg.html "On the History of Statistics and Actuarial Science at The University of Iowa" presented by Robert V. Hogg on October 2, 2003] * {{MathGenealogy |id=7015 }} * [http://www.ams.org/mathscinet/search/author.html?mrauthid=87200&Submit=Search Hogg at] [[Mathematical Reviews]] {{statistics|state=collapsed}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hogg, Robert Vincent}} [[Category:Presidents of the American Statistical Association]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Statistical Association]] [[Category:Fellows of the Institute of Mathematical Statistics]] [[Category:Elected Members of the International Statistical Institute]] [[Category:American statisticians]] [[Category:Statistics educators]] [[Category:20th-century American mathematicians]] [[Category:21st-century American mathematicians]] [[Category:University of Iowa faculty]] [[Category:University of Iowa alumni]] [[Category:University of Illinois alumni]] [[Category:People from Hannibal, Missouri]] [[Category:1924 births]] [[Category:2014 deaths]] [[Category:People from Highlands Ranch, Colorado]]

revision.text:
The '''Rostock Matrikelportal''' ([[matriculation]] portal) disseminates about 186,000 individual-level datasets drawn from the student registers of the [[University of Rostock]] from its establishment in 1419 to today. Each entry is faithfully transcribed and linked with a digitzed image of a student’s original, partly handwritten register entry. Users may search and comment on individual entries thus expanding the information on single students. Places of origin are [[Geotagging|geo-tagged]] and displayed on interactive maps. Additional links refer to professors that were active at the time of matriculation (see: [[Catalogus Professorum Rostochiensium]]) and lectures held. [[Integrated Authority File]]s (GNDs) identify notable students and interlink them with further personal data web portals and platforms on the Internet.<ref>[http://matrikel.uni-rostock.de/ Main page of the Rostock Matrikelportal], accessed on April, 12th, 2014</ref>
== References == <references />
== External links == * {{LBMV PPN|54690243X}} * [http://matrikel.uni-rostock.de/ Rostock Matrikelportal] * [http://cpr.uni-rostock.de/ Catalogus Professorum Rostochiensium]
[[Category:University of Rostock]] [[Category:History of universities]] [[Category:2008 establishments in Germany]] [[Category:Online person databases]]

revision.text:
{{POV|date=January 2013}} The '''School Prayer Amendment''' is a [[Article Five of the United States Constitution|proposed amendment]] to the [[United States Constitution]] intended by its proponents to protect the right of the students if they wish, to voluntarily pray in schools, although opponents argue it allows for government sponsored prayer.
==Background== In the cases ''[[Engel v. Vitale]]'' (1962) and ''[[Abington School District v. Schempp]]'' (1963), the [[United States Supreme Court]] ruled that [[government mandated school prayer]] is unconstitutional under the [[Establishment Clause]] of the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]]. However voluntary prayer is not unconstitutional.
The history of school prayer amendment began in 1962 with the Supreme Court case of Engel v. Vitale. A New York policy required schools to begin each day with a word of prayer. Regarding this case, Justice Hugo Black wrote "… the constitutional prohibition against laws respecting an establishment of religion must at least mean that in this country it is no part of the business of government to compose official prayers for any group of the American people to recite as a part of a religious program carried on by government."
The next year, a similar case arose: Abington Township School District v. Schempp. The effect of this incident was the prohibition of school officials from organizing or leading prayers as well as devotional Bible reading in public schools. Abington v. Schempp required that school faculties should neither promote nor degrade religion. The Supreme Court next examined school prayer in 1985 with the case of [[Wallace v. Jaffree]]. A change to Alabama's moment-of-silence law included a requirement that the moment of silence must be for "meditation or voluntary prayer." The Court saw the change as government promotion of prayer in the schools, and overturned the change to the law. The justices explained that a moment of silence is appropriate, but not for any religious purpose. <ref>http://www.firstamendmentcenter.org/school-prayer</ref>
==Text==
{{blockquote| Article--
SECTION 1. To secure the people's right to acknowledge God according to the dictates of conscience: The people's right to pray and to recognize their religious beliefs, heritage, or traditions on public property, including schools, shall not be infringed. The Government shall not require any person to join in prayer or other religious activity, initiate or designate school prayers, discriminate against religion, or deny equal access to a benefit on account of religion..<ref name="Thomas">http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/D?c105:1:./temp/~c105zjXWvc::</ref>}}
=== H. J. RES. 16 ===
{{blockquote| Article—
Nothing in this Constitution shall be construed to prohibit individual or group prayer in public schools or other public institutions. No person shall be required by the United States or by any State to participate in prayer. Neither the United States nor any State shall prescribe the content of any such prayer.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Emerson|first1=Bill|title=Proposing an amendment to the Constitution of the United States relating to voluntary school prayer.|url=https://www.congress.gov/bill/104th-congress/house-joint-resolution/16|website=Congress.gob|publisher=Library of Congress|accessdate=21 March 2018|quote=Resolved by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress assembled (two-thirds of each House concurring therein), That the following article is hereby proposed as an amendment to the Constitution of the United States, which shall be valid to all intents and purposes as part of the Constitution if ratified by the legislatures of at least three-fourths of the several States within seven years from the date of its proposal to the States by the Congress: ``Article-- ``Nothing in this Constitution shall be construed to prohibit individual or group prayer in public schools or other public institutions. No person shall be required by the United States or by any State to participate in prayer. Neither the United States nor any State shall prescribe the content of any such prayer.}}''</ref>}}
==History== [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Robert Byrd]] of [[West Virginia]] proposed the amendment in 1962, 1973, 1979, 1982, 1993, 1995, and 1997.<ref name="Byrd 2006">{{cite news|url=http://www.firstamendmentcenter.org/news.aspx?id=16832|title=Sen. Byrd introduces amendment allowing school prayer|date=2006-04-30|publisher=Associated Press|accessdate=2009-01-31|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://swap.stanford.edu/20090125041326/http%3A//www.firstamendmentcenter.org/news.aspx?id%3D16832|archivedate=2009-01-25|df=}}</ref>
''[[The New York Times]]'' reported in July 1999 that the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]], at that time occupied by a Republican majority, had long been proposing such an amendment but was preoccupied with a competing, more general amendment allowing for "religious freedoms" proposed by [[Henry Hyde]], then-Chairman of the [[House Judiciary Committee]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A0CE0D61E39F935A25754C0A960958260|title=Republicans in Congress Renew Push for Vote on School Prayer Amendment |last=Seelye|first=Katharine Q.|date=1996-07-16|work=The New York Times|accessdate=2009-01-31}}</ref> Representative [[Ernest Istook]], a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] from [[Oklahoma's 5th congressional district]], proposed the amendment on May 8, 1997.<ref name="Thomas">http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/bdquery/z?d105:HJ00078:@@@L&summ2=m&</ref> In March 1998, the Judiciary Committee passed the bill by a 16-11 vote.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/ALLPOLITICS/1998/04/20/time/pols.schoolprayer.html|title=Spiriting Prayer Into School|last=Van Biema|first=David|date=1998-04-27|work=Time|accessdate=2009-01-31}}</ref> On June 4, 1998, the full House voted on the amendment, 224-203 in favor.<ref name="Thomas"/> The vote was 61 short of the two-thirds majority required by [[Article Five of the United States Constitution]] to propose a constitutional amendment.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C03EED61F3BF934A35755C0A96E958260|title=Votes in Congress |date=1998-06-07|work=The New York Times|accessdate=2009-01-31}}</ref>
Istook reintroduced the amendment to Congress twice: first in 1999 as the House Joint Resolution 66<ref>http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c106:H.J.RES.66.IH:</ref> and in 2001 as the "Religious Speech Amendment".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.au.org/site/News2?abbr=pr&page=NewsArticle&id=6009 |title=Rep. Istook to Reintroduce School Prayer Amendment to U.S. Constitution |date=2001-10-29 |publisher=Americans United for Separation of Church and State |accessdate=2009-01-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081129165838/http://www.au.org/site/News2?abbr=pr&page=NewsArticle&id=6009 |archivedate=November 29, 2008 }}</ref> Byrd proposed the amendment again on April 29, 2006.<ref name="Byrd 2006"/>
Though the proposed amendment failed to be adopted, it led to the passing of the [[Equal Access Act]].
[[Rick Perry]], governor of [[Texas]] and Republican [[Republican Party presidential primaries, 2012|a former candidate for the 2012 presidential election]], said in an interview on ''[[Fox News Sunday]]'' on December 11, 2011: "I would support a constitutional amendment that allows our children to pray in school anytime they would like."<ref>{{cite news|last=Schoenberg|first=Shira|title=Rick Perry calls for constitutional amendment allowing school prayers|url=http://www.boston.com/Boston/politicalintelligence/2011/12/rick-perry-calls-for-constitutional-amendment-allowing-school-prayers/4GML6nut9s5eLz5n7MUGiL/index.html|accessdate=December 16, 2011|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=December 12, 2011}}</ref>
==Reception== The [[Freedom From Religion Foundation]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ffrf.org/publications/brochures/item/14113-schoolprayer|title=The Case Against School Prayer|last=Gaylor|first=Annie Laurie|authorlink=Annie Laurie Gaylor |year=1995|publisher=Freedom From Religion Foundation|accessdate=2009-01-31}}</ref> [[American Civil Liberties Union]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aclu.org/religion/gen/16039res20020311.html|title=Constitutional Amendment on School Prayer|date=2002-03-11|publisher=American Civil Liberties Union|accessdate=2009-01-31}}</ref> and [[Americans United for Separation of Church and State]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.org/site/News2?abbr=pr&page=NewsArticle&id=5110 |title=Istook School Prayer Amendment Unnecessary, Divisive And Dangerous, Says Americans United |date=2003-04-08 |publisher=Americans United for Separation of Church and State |accessdate=2009-01-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081129154043/http://www.au.org/site/News2?abbr=pr&page=NewsArticle&id=5110 |archivedate=November 29, 2008 }}</ref> have all expressed opposition to this amendment. The [[Family Research Council]] has supported it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rightwingwatch.org/content/family-research-council|title=Family Research Council|date=2008-08-25|work=Right Wing Watch|publisher=People for the American Way|accessdate=2009-02-01}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Proposed amendments to the United States Constitution]] [[Category:Religion and education]] [[Category:Religion and children]] [[Category:Prayer]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/62.255.130.218|62.255.130.218]] ([[User talk:62.255.130.218|talk]]) to last revision by AndrewWTaylor. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{For|Tawse as a genealogical branch of the Scottish [[Clan Farquharson]]|Sept (social)}} [[File:Examples of the tawse, made in Lochgelly. An exhibit in the Abbot House, Dunfermline..jpg|thumb|280px|Museum specimens of the tawse]]
{{corporal punishment}} The '''tawse''', sometimes formerly spelled '''taws''' (the plural of [[Scots language|Scots]] '''taw''', a thong of a whip) is an implement used for [[corporal punishment]]. It was used for [[School corporal punishment|educational discipline]], primarily in [[Scotland]], but also in schools in the English cities of [[Newcastle upon Tyne]], [[Gateshead]], [[Manchester]] and [[Walsall]].
A tawse consists of a strip of [[leather]], with one end split into a number of tails. The thickness of the leather and the number of tails is variable. Many Scottish saddlers made tawses for local schoolmasters. The official name "tawse" was hardly ever used in conversation by either teachers or pupils, who instead referred to it as either '''the school strap''' or '''the belt''', the normal term for an unforked implement, as worn in trousers (see [[Belt (clothing)|belt]]).
[[State school#Scotland|Scottish public (state) schools]] used the tawse to punish pupils of either sex on the palm of the outstretched hand. Pupils were usually instructed to hold out one hand, palm uppermost, supported by the other hand below, which made it difficult to move the hand away during the infliction of the strokes. It also ensured that the full force of each stroke was taken by the hand being strapped. The punishment was usually inflicted by the class teacher in front of the entire class, to act as a deterrent to others; sometimes by a designated teacher, such as the Deputy Headmaster, to whom the pupil was sent.
In Walsall and Gateshead, and in some schools in Manchester and [[Nottingham]], male students were tawsed on the [[buttocks|seat of the trousers]].
Some [[Independent school#Scotland|Scottish private (independent) schools]] also used the tawse, such as [[Keil School]], but others such as [[Fettes College]] used the cane instead, as did most schools in England outside the north-east.
In 1982 two Scottish mothers went to the [[European Court of Human Rights]], who passed a judgment that parents had the right to refuse corporal punishment of a child.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=uLdAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yaUMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2319%2C4771823 |title=Victor in belt case set to sue |first=John |last=Linklater |work=The Glasgow Herald |date=26 February 1982 |page=1 |accessdate=28 January 2017}}</ref> This judgement led indirectly to the use of the tawse (and all other forms of corporal punishment) being banned by law in UK state schools. The legislation came into force in 1987, but most Scottish local education authorities had already abolished it by the early 1980s.
John J. Dick Leather Goods was a manufacturer in [[Lochgelly]] estimated to have made around 70% of tawses when they were used in schools.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-39044445 |title=How the tawse left its mark on Scottish pupils |work=BBC News |date=22 February 2017 |accessdate=13 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite AV media |url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p04qz9s8 |title=Making the Lochgelly Tawse |work=BBC |date=20 February 2017 |accessdate=13 March 2017}}</ref> Original tawses sold for around £6 in 1982 but twenty years later some collectors were paying hundred of pounds each for rare items.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.scotsman.com/news/cash-strapped-teachers-offer-shy-collectors-six-of-the-best-1-1378698 |title=Cash-strapped teachers offer shy collectors six of the best |work=The Scotsman |location= Edinburgh |date=25 August 2002 |accessdate=13 March 2016}}</ref>
The tawse was also used for [[judicial corporal punishment]] in Scotland as an alternative to the more usual birch. Courts could sentence boys of over 14 but under 16 to up to 36 strokes with an extra-heavy tawse for any offence. This was administered to the offender's bare buttocks. Judicial corporal punishment was abolished in 1948.
== See also == * [[Corporal punishment]] * [[School discipline]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Sources and external links== * [http://www.corpun.com/scotland.htm The Cane and the Tawse in Scottish Schools], article at World Corporal Punishment Research * {{cite web |last= |first= |date= | publisher=[[Glasgow Caledonian University]] |title= The Belt (Factsheet 12) |url= http://www.gcu.ac.uk/heatherbank/pdfs/fs12belt.pdf |work= Heatherbank Museum of Social Work |location= [[Glasgow]] |access-date= 2017-07-16| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100601215648/http://www.gcu.ac.uk/heatherbank/pdfs/fs12belt.pdf | dead-url= yes | archivedate= 2010-06-01 | quote= }} * [http://www.johndick-leathergoods.co.uk/the-true-history-of-the-lochgelly-tawse-memories.html The True History of the Lochgelly Tawse]
[[Category:Education in Scotland]] [[Category:School punishments]] [[Category:Social history of Scotland]] [[Category:Spanking implements]] [[Category:History of education in Scotland]] [[Category:Goods manufactured in Scotland]] [[Category:Corporal punishments]]

{{advert|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox university | name = Unity University | native_name = ዩኒቲ ዩኒቨርስቲ | image_name = Unity_University_logo.png | image_size = 200px | caption = [[Seal (emblem)|Seal]] of the Unity University | latin_name = | motto = ''Quality House'' | established = 1998 | closed = | language = English | type = [[Private university|Private]] | president = Dr. Arega Yirdaw | head_label = Founder | head = Fisseha Eshetu<ref>{{cite news |title=Ethiopia: Tertiary Education - Its Quantity And Quality |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200708180098.html |work=[[Ethiopian Reporter|The Reporter]] |date=18 August 2007 |accessdate=27 July 2009|first=Lule Belay|last=Haile}}</ref> | faculty = 76 | students = 5,193 | undergrad = | postgrad = | other = | city = [[Addis Ababa]] | country = [[Ethiopia]] | coor = {{Coord|9|0|12.29|N|38|48|11.51|E|region:IN_type:edu|display=inline, title}} | campus = Gerji, Nazreth and Dessie | former_names = Unity University College | nickname = Unity | website = {{URL|www.uu.edu.et}} | logo = | footnotes = }} '''Unity University''' is the first privately owned institute of higher learning to be awarded full-fledged university status in Ethiopia by the Ministry of Education. It is also the first [[private university]] in the country to offer postgraduate programs leading to [[Master's degree|master’s degree]] in [[Master of Business Administration|business administration]] (MBA) and [[development economics]] (MA).
==History== Established in 1991, Unity [[language school]] was offering English, Arabic, French and Italian language courses. It started with not more than 50 students, a few part-time teachers and administration personnel. Progressively, the institute launched diploma programs in accounting, marketing, business, personnel administration, secretarial science and office management from 1997 to 1999. In March 1998 the institute was upgraded to a college level,following its achievements in education, becoming the first privately owned college in Ethiopia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.addistribune.com/Archives/2001/12/28-12-01/Unity.htm|title=Unity College Graduates Students|date=28 December 2001|work=Addis Tribune|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080209140131/http://www.addistribune.com/Archives/2001/12/28-12-01/Unity.htm|archivedate=9 February 2008|dead-url=yes|accessdate=11 August 2009}}</ref> Through the years, the institute has played a pioneering role in providing quality education, setting a fine record. Later named Unity College, the institute has promoted innovative approaches and launched degree programs in various disciplines. Unity was promoted to university level in September 2008, becoming the first privately owned university. It has since been known as Unity University,(U.U.).
==Role== In addition to its educational role, the university encourages research and holds annual multi-disciplinary conferences. The proceedings of these conferences are published in its academic journal, ''The Ethiopian Journal of Business and Development''.
Unity University is also very active in [[community service]] programs. It is involved in activities related to [[Environmental movement|environmental protection]], and has participated in the "Clean and Green Addis Ababa" initiative, and in other programs sponsored by the city council and [[chamber of commerce]] of Addis Ababa, such as [[HIV]] and [[AIDS]] awareness and prevention.
The university offers scholarships to students with financial difficulties, including a girls’ project, which extends assistance to deserving female students who lack financial resources. It also gives scholarships to its own staff who wish to upgrade their academic status, and to students with outstanding records in sports and other cultural activities. now
==Size== As of January 2012 the student population was 5,193, with 324 enrolled in the postgraduate program, 4,313 in undergraduate studies, and 556 in TVET programs including distance and continuing programs offered at its various centers. Unity has seventy-six academic staff of which five are women.
==Requirements== *Postgraduate **For MBA and MBA specializing marketing - Holders of bachelor's degrees from recognized colleges and universities in such disciplines as management, marketing management, accounting, economics, engineering, medicine, public administration, political science among others. **For MA in development economics: Holders of bachelor’s degrees in economics and related fields of specialization from recognized colleges and universities. *Undergraduate **As per the policies and regulations of the ministry of education (MOE) for admission to a tertiary level education institution in Ethiopia. ***Completion of college preparatory school and with 360 and above points ***GPA 3.00 and above in ESLCE for female applicants and GPA of 3.2 and above in ESLCE for male applicants. ***Graduate from recognized universities and colleges can also apply for admission in advance standing or otherwise. *Levels **As per the policies and regulation of the MOE for admission to technical and vocational education and training (TVET) programs.
==Duration== *Postgraduate **Regular - Two years **Extension - Three years *Undergraduate **Regular - Four to six years
== Programs == {{div col}} * [[Undergraduate]] ** [[Accounting]] ** [[Economics]] ** [[Management]] ** [[Marketing management]] ** [[Management information systems]] ** [[Computer science]] ** [[Architecture and urban planning]] ** [[Civil engineering]] ** [[Mining engineering]] ** Sociology and social anthropology ** [[Clinical nursing]] * [[Postgraduate]] ** [[Master of business administration]] ** Master of business administration (specialization in marketing) ** MA in development economics ** MA in business economics * TVET (Level) **Accounting **Marketing/salesmanship **Information technology assistant **Clinical nursing **ICT and system support * Distance and continuing education ** Accounting **Management **Marketing management **Economics **English * Executive training programs **Effective communication and team dynamics **Leadership essentials and team dynamics **Strategic leadership and supervisory management **Innovative leadership and entrepreneurship skills development **Employees performance appraisal **Finance for none finance managers **[[Database administration]] **Business plan preparation and grant proposal writing **Maintenance management system **Budget preparation and control management **Secretarial professionals' development program **Positive thinking **Customer service delivery **Ethics in the workplace {{div col end}}
==Facilities== *[[Library]] *Computer labs with broadband Internet access *Printing house *[[Bookstore]] *TV and radio studio *Sport facilities *Cafeteria services *[[Clinic]] *[[Pharmacy]]
==Notable alumni== *[[Bethlehem Tilahun Alemu]], businesswoman, class of 2004.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Tekletsadik|first1=Melat|last2=Berhanu|first2=Betel Bekele|title=Bethlehem Tilahun Alemu|url=http://www.ethiopianwomenunleashed.org/profile_detail.php?PId=54|website=www.ethiopianwomenunleashed.org|accessdate=25 June 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140924115935/http://www.ethiopianwomenunleashed.org/profile_detail.php?PId=54|archivedate=24 September 2014|df=}}</ref> *[[Amleset Muchie]] , Actress and model (also wife of Teddy Afro). She studied Journalism.
==See also== * [[Education in Ethiopia]] * [[List of universities and colleges in Ethiopia]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links ==
