revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox university | name =The University of West Alabama | image_name=UWALogo.png | image_size=150px | motto="Do Something That Matters." | established=1835 | type=[[State university system|Public University]] | endowment=$375,613{{cite news|url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/livingston-al/west-alabama-1024|title=Best Colleges 2010|publisher=U.S. News & World Report|accessdate=February 22, 2010}} | president=Dr. Ken Tucker | provost=Dr. Timothy Edwards | city=[[Livingston, Alabama|Livingston]] | state=[[Alabama]] | country=United States| | former_names={{small|{{nowrap|Livingston Female Academy (1835–1878)}}
{{nowrap|Livingston Normal College (1878–1929)}}
{{nowrap|Livingston State Teachers College (1929–1957)}}
{{nowrap|Livingston State College (1957–1967)}}
{{nowrap|Livingston University (1967–1995)}}}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2DodAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EKYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3362,2882833&dq=university-of-west-alabama&hl=en|title=LU name change idea doesn't fly|date=February 10, 1995|publisher=[[Tuscaloosa News]]|accessdate=February 6, 2010}} | faculty=97 | enrollment=5,157 | campus=Rural, {{convert|600|acre|km2|abbr=on|sigfig=3}} | colors=Red and White {{color box|#FF0000}}{{color box|#FFFFFF}} | athletics=[[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[NCAA Division II|Division II]] – [[Gulf South Conference|Gulf South]] | nickname=[[West Alabama Tigers|Tigers]] | mascot=Luie the Tiger | affiliations=[[Alabama Commission on Higher Education|ACHE]], [[Southern Association of Colleges and Schools|SACS]] | address=The University of West Alabama Livingston, AL 35470 | website={{URL|www.uwa.edu}} }} '''The University of West Alabama''' (abbreviated as '''UWA''') is a public university located in [[Livingston, Alabama]], United States. Founded in 1835, the school began as a church-supported school for young women called '''Livingston Female Academy'''. The original Board of Trustees of Livingston Female Academy was selected in 1836, and four of the seven board members were [[Presbyterian]]s. The university serves students in several academic colleges and divisions on a {{convert|600|acre|km2|adj=on}} campus in west-central Alabama. UWA offers a wide arrangement of degree programs including associate, bachelor's, master's,educational specialist, and educational doctorate degrees.{{cite news|url=http://www.uwa.edu/admissions/undergraduate/academics|title=Academic Programs|publisher=The University of West Alabama|accessdate=February 6, 2010}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The university hosts concerts, lectures, fall and spring theatrical productions, fall and spring commencement exercises, and intercollegiate athletic events. Its athletics teams, known as the [[West Alabama Tigers]], are members of the [[Gulf South Conference]] and compete in the [[NCAA]]'s [[NCAA Division II|Division II]] in all sports except two.{{cite web|url=http://www.gulfsouthconference.org/about.asp?page=schools|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070207122751/http://www.gulfsouthconference.org/about.asp?page=schools|dead-url=yes|archive-date=February 7, 2007|title=Gulf South Conference-About the Gulf South Conference|publisher=Gulf South Conference|date=January 1, 2007|accessdate=February 6, 2010}} The men's and women's rodeo teams compete in the Ozark Region of the [[National Intercollegiate Rodeo Association]].{{cite web|url=http://www.collegerodeo.com/membership/RegionInfo.asp?Region=OZ|title=NIRA-Membership for Ozark Region|publisher=National Intercollegiate Rodeo Association|date=January 1, 2007|accessdate=February 7, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120729072432/http://www.collegerodeo.com/membership/RegionInfo.asp?Region=OZ|archivedate=July 29, 2012|df=mdy-all}} == History == === Early history === The University of West Alabama began as '''Livingston Female Academy''' in 1835.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Az4dAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dqYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3520,4334527&dq=livingston+female+academy&hl=en|title=College, small-town life intersect in Livingston|date=March 24, 2002|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=1B|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} As a church-related female academy, it admitted its first students in 1839. The school was established by [[ethnic]] [[Scotch-Irish American|Scots-Irish]] Presbyterians, who controlled the majority of seats on the first board of trustees selected in 1836. The purpose of the school was to educate future teachers, while also offering course work in art, music, languages, and home economics.{{cite news|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=C6AWAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA100&lpg=PA100&dq=livingston+female+academy&source=bl&ots=WnGY6uMiSm&sig=A2FVm3w98WgaPBIzxNN-Y2laVIo&hl=en&ei=cZSVS47VMqCQmAeo5PyaCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CAwQ6AEwAzge#v=onepage&q=livingston%20female%20academy&f=false|title=History of Higher Education of Women in the South|last=Blandin|first=I.M.E|year=1909|work=The Neale Publishing Company|pages=100–101|accessdate=March 8, 2010}} Tuition at this time was $20 annually with an additional $25 charged for piano lessons and $10 for French language and [[embroidery]].{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=aBkfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=C5wEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4975,2299182&dq=livingston+female+academy&hl=en|title=1847 college ad proves passage of time makes remarkable change in living costs|date=December 11, 1969|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=30|accessdate=March 23, 2010}} Jones Hall was the first building constructed on the campus in 1837, and was located near what is now Brock Hall. (The building was lost to fire in the 1890s). On January 15, 1840, state lawmakers incorporated Livingston Female Academy, granted it tax-exempt status, and gave the board the authority to establish rules and regulations.{{cite news|url=http://meridianstar.com/editorials/x681144390/Sumter-County-Alabama-Our-neighbors-to-the-East|title=Sumter County Alabama–Our Neighbors to the East|last=McKee|first=Anne|date=December 11, 2008|work=Meridian Star|accessdate=March 8, 2010}} [[File:JuliaTutwiler.jpg|right|thumb|Julia Tutwiler]] Livingston Female Academy awarded its first diploma in 1843 to Elizabeth Houston, the daughter of M. L. Houston, a prominent local businessman and a school trustee. The first principal of the school was A. A. Kimbrell, followed by Margaret McShan. In 1853, Dr. Robert Dickens Webb arrived in Sumter County and served as a trustee for more than 40 years. He led the school during the [[American Civil War]] and Reconstruction through the 1870s, helping to keep the institution open. The main administration building that sits in the middle of campus today is named in his honor. In 1878, the institution changed its name to '''Livingston Normal College'''. Education reformer [[Julia Tutwiler|Julia Strudwick Tutwiler]] joined the faculty in 1881 as co-principal with her uncle, [[Carlos Green Smith]], former president of the [[University of Alabama]].{{cite news|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ffXf-VnSlTsC&pg=PA11&lpg=PA11&dq=livingston+female+academy&source=bl&ots=jH--ek2wuf&sig=KpaoEX9t3tqLpqKFG5PwwMK03V0&hl=en&ei=TZiVS5z3NNCEmQex_6yPBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CBEQ6AEwBTg8#v=onepage&q=livingston%20female%20academy&f=false |title=Stories of the Haunted South|last=Brown|first=Alan|year=2004|work=University Press of Mississippi|page=11|accessdate=March 8, 2010}} In 1882–1883, state lawmakers provided $2,500 for tuition and supplies; Alabama was the first southern state to fund the education of women. Tutwiler and state legislator Addison Gillespie Smith helped secure this appropriation.{{cite news|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xlcdAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA71&lpg=PA71&dq=livingston+female+academy&source=bl&ots=hn9e6cTSjl&sig=IMUq0BgIx0lAbL7qSDeZIdd0cC4&hl=en&ei=BgiXS4maGtKW8AbY6JwM&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CBcQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=livingston%20female%20academy&f=false|title=Public School Laws of the State of Alabama|last=Turner|first=John|year=1895|work=Roemer Printing Company|pages=70–74|accessdate=March 9, 2010}} In 1883, the school was renamed the Alabama Normal College for Girls and Livingston Female Academy, to better reflect the new mission of the institution, providing students with choices of either two- or four-year programs.{{cite news|url=http://www.montgomeryadvertiser.com/article/20100227/NEWS02/2270332/1009/Reed-organ-represents-heritage-of-University-of-West-Alabama|title=Reed organ represents heritage of University of West Alabama|last=Rupinski|first=Patrick|date=February 27, 2010|work=Montgomery Advertiser|accessdate=March 10, 2010}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} "Normal training" was the term used at that time to describe teacher education that represented high school plus two years of college education. The Normal College presented its first diplomas at the 1886 [[commencement speech|commencement]] exercises. In 1890, Tutwiler was named president of the college.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=HjAdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=1p4EAAAAIBAJ&pg=3257,7307276&dq=livingston+normal+college+julia+tutwiler&hl=en|title=Woman heads college|date=November 28, 1979|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=3|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} She is the only woman to have been president. During her tenure, Tutwiler aided in establishing the Alabama Girls' Industrial Institute (now the [[University of Montevallo]]) and in having the first women admitted to the [[University of Alabama]] in 1893.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1817&dat=19760920&id=2xgfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=8J0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=5858,5137571|title=Livingston, Alabama; a city with a rich heritage and a bright future|date=September 20, 1976|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=7|accessdate=March 8, 2010}} In the early 20th century new leadership brought a new name to the college as well. George William Brock was hired by the trustees in 1907 to oversee the institution's financial affairs. Following Tutwiler's retirement in 1910, Brock assumed the presidency.{{cite news|url=http://www.encyclopediaofalabama.org/face/Article.jsp?id=h-1112|title=Julia S. Tutwiler|work=Encyclopedia of Alabama|accessdate=March 11, 2010}} Alumni began meeting in honor of Tutwiler in 1910 and formed the first alumni association. Men were admitted to the institution as regular students in 1915.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bGEeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=msgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2485,5379976&dq=livingston+female+academy&hl=en|title=Livingston's 150th|date=March 21, 1986|work=Times Daily|page=12A|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} Foust Hall was built in 1922 as a lab school where college professors taught, and students observed and participated in classroom instruction. The building's open-air plan with a central courtyard became a building design familiar to many Alabamians. In 1928, both Bibb Graves Hall and Brock Hall were added to the physical plant under this plan.{{cite news|url=http://www.encyclopediaofalabama.org/face/Article.jsp?id=h-2358|title=A History of Livingston University, 1835–1963|last=Lyon|first=Ralph M|year=1976|publisher=Encyclopedia of Alabama|accessdate=February 6, 2010}} === State university === [[File:AlamucheeCB.jpg|left|thumb|The [[Alamuchee-Bellamy Covered Bridge]] on campus]] In 1929, the Alabama State Board of Education took over supervision and renamed the facility the '''Livingston State Teachers College'''. Under George William Brock, in 1929 the school founded a student newspaper called ''Campus Lights'' (now called ''The Muse''). A football team was added in 1931. With striped uniforms, the college took the tiger as its mascot, and the sports teams continue to be known as the [[West Alabama Tigers|UWA Tigers]]; red and white are the school colors.{{cite news|url=http://www.uwa.edu/Media/Website%20Resources/thelife/2010/March%203.pdf|title=We are the Tigers|date=March 3, 2010|work=The Life|pages=1–2|accessdate=March 23, 2010}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} After president Brock retired in 1936, Noble Franklin Greenhill took over and served until 1944. Under Greenhill, campus life flourished as social sororities and intercollegiate sports in baseball, basketball, and football were added.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=AOohAAAAIBAJ&sjid=0ZkEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5329,3758198&dq=livingston+state+teachers+college&hl=en|title=Livingston State sororities have rush week activities|date=October 2, 1955|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=21|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} The first [[homecoming]] celebration was held in 1939. World War II brought such a decline in enrollment that the college nearly closed. When William Wilson Hill assumed the presidency in 1944 after Greenhill left, he commissioned studies to determine if the institution should continue as a four-year college.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LgwsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KLoEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4430,1927988&dq=livingston+state+teachers+college&hl=en|title=State teachers’ college at Livingston is studied|date=August 29, 1944|work=Times Daily|pages=2–3|accessdate=March 8, 2010}} Hill began with only 92 students, so he set out to recruit [[veterans]]. With more men on campus, the interest in sports was revived, and servicemen were aided financially in going to college by the [[GI Bill]], which increased the educational level of a generation of men. [[Tiger Stadium (West Alabama)|Tiger Stadium]] was built in 1952. The first campus fraternities were established during Wilson's presidency.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=c2QeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7JkEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7370,5323634&dq=livingston+state+teachers+college&hl=en|title=Plans, projects, happenings at Livingston State College|date=October 14, 1956|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=24|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} The college gained a reputation for teacher education in the region and state through the 1940s, 1950s, and 1960s.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QIkfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=85kEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7198,3431127&dq=livingston+state+teachers+college&hl=en|title=Livingston State College classrooms filled to capacity|last=Ennis|first=Richard|date=September 27, 1959|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=27|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} The mission of the institution was broadened in 1957 when, under the leadership of Delos Culp (1954–1963), the school's name was changed to '''Livingston State College'''.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=TPkcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=AZoEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3836,3839209&dq=livingston+state+college&hl=en|title=Livingston State enrollment near all-time high with 600|last=Watkins|first=Ed|date=October 30, 1957|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=6|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} Graduate-level classes were added, and the state board of education began awarding master's degrees in professional education under a new graduate division.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7ewhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=45kEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6263,6091730&dq=livingston+state+teachers+college&hl=en|title=Summer quarter classes begin at Livingston State College|date=June 16, 1957|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=8|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} Kelly Hester Land was awarded the first master's degree, and a writing scholarship competition and building are named for her.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kxQfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5p0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=3910,6466302&dq=livingston+state+teachers+college&hl=en|title=For 3 LU retirees, ninety years service|date=May 30, 1976|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=3A|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} Under John E. Deloney (1963–1973), the college had substantial growth, so it expanded its campus, to more than {{convert|540|acre|km2}} with a {{convert|54|acre|m2|adj=on}} lake surrounded by nature trails, open to the community as well as college population.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2fAjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HZsEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5065,2827211&dq=livingston+state+college&hl=en|title=Livingston State will expand|last=Watkins|first=Ed|date=June 17, 1966|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=1|accessdate=March 7, 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Aw8fAAAAIBAJ&sjid=D5sEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7123,4771677&dq=livingston+state+teachers+college&hl=en|title=Quiet little college town gets a modern-day glow|last=Watkins|first=Ed|date=October 31, 1965|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=22|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} In 1967, the U.S. Office of Education approved a grant for the institution to receive campus renovations and updates.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nHwhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=pIoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=7391,4681377&dq=livingston+state+teachers+college&hl=en|title=Livingston State receives grant to update college|date=April 26, 1987|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=14|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} During the same year, an act of the Legislature created '''Livingston University''' with its own Board of Trustees.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=dwAdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=OZsEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6010,5210010&dq=livingston+university+name&hl=en|title=Faculty, students are happy with new university status|date=April 28, 1968|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=39|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} In 1969, a longtime historic landmark in [[Sumter County, Alabama|Sumter County]], the Alamuchee-Bellamy Covered Bridge (built 1861), was restored and moved on campus by the Sumter County Historical Society.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PRUfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7Z0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=5588,828167&dq=livingston+university&hl=en|title=LU has covered bridge|last=Watkins|first=Ed|date=July 4, 1976|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=15B|accessdate=March 9, 2010}} It spans the northeast corner of Duck Pond behind Reed Hall. The number of faculty was increased during Deloney's presidency as well, and the school's colleges and divisions started taking shape.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9BAdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KZwEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7411,5946930&dq=livingston+university&hl=en|title=Faculty growth important at Livingston|date=January 30, 1972|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=9A|accessdate=March 8, 2010}} In 1973, Asa N. Green (1973–1994) became president; he oversaw the establishment of the Ira D. Pruitt School of Nursing and dual-degree programs with [[Auburn University]] and the [[University of Alabama at Birmingham]]. He worked to establish a consortium of 13 schools to create a [[marine biology]] program and the [[Dauphin Island]] Sea Lab.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Im00AAAAIBAJ&sjid=B54EAAAAIBAJ&pg=3642,6043206&dq=history+of+livingston+university&hl=en|title=LU may triple enrollment in 30 years|date=January 29, 1978|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=9C|accessdate=March 8, 2010}} More buildings were added and renovated across campus.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=H4o0AAAAIBAJ&sjid=lKUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4398,6452945&dq=history+of+livingston+university&hl=en|title=Livingston University renews commitment to future|date=January 25, 1987|work=Tuscaloosa News|pages=14H-15H|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} During the late 1970s, an area was reserved on campus for the construction of Lake LU. Pre-professional programs were established, and the first Ira D. Pruitt Division of Nursing class earned associate degrees in 1976.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EiEfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9J0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=6813,6041660&dq=livingston+university&hl=en|title=Waterway to have impact on LU|date=January 30, 1977|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=18H|accessdate=March 8, 2010}} Overall, 153 degrees were awarded during commencement exercises in May that same year.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kxQfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5p0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=6915,6540637&dq=livingston+university&hl=en|title=Livingston University awards degrees to 153|date=May 30, 1976|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=19A|accessdate=March 8, 2010}} In 1977, Dr. Ralph M. Lyon, University educator and administrator, retired from his position, and was honored for his tenure. His wife presented the University with a handcrafted [[ceremonial mace]] in his dedication.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=VggdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_Z0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=6699,453150&dq=livingston+university&hl=en|title=Livingston University pays honor to Dr. Lyons|date=June 2, 1977|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=8|accessdate=March 8, 2010}} The mace is used at yearly commencement exercises. Not long after the 1977 commencement, history professor William E. Gilbert was found dead off campus.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=WwgdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_Z0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=4232,1911495&dq=livingston+university&hl=en|title=LU professor found dead|last=Watkins|first=Ed|date=June 9, 1977|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=1|accessdate=March 8, 2010}} In the early 1980s, a new computer system was installed on campus to support the University's computer information processing systems major.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=niUdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=TqUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5323,5920104&dq=livingston+university&hl=en|title=Livingston University gets a new computer system|date=February 28, 1982|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=26A|accessdate=March 8, 2010}} During the 1985–1986 academic year, the University observed its 150th anniversary.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2FspAAAAIBAJ&sjid=k6UEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3767,6882774&dq=livingston+normal+college+julia+tutwiler&hl=en|title=Livingston marks sesquicentennial; looks ahead|date=January 26, 1986 November 1979|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=2H|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} After Green resigned, Don C. Hines (1994–1998) assumed the post of president and brought additional change.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=FUggAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vaUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3823,8302725&dq=livingston+university+football&hl=en|title=LU to inaugurate president|last=Watkins|first=Ed|date=September 26, 1994|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=4B|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} Today, the [[rodeo]] complex on campus is named in his honor. Among students, Hines is most remembered for bringing collegiate rodeo to campus.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=VTwdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KaYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6670,4949393&dq=livingston+university&hl=en|title=LU to field rodeo team|date=January 18, 1995|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=6C|accessdate=March 8, 2010}}{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=qmAeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-scEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2075,2274449&dq=livingston+university&hl=en|title=Livingston adds rodeo as sport|date=January 18, 1995|work=Times Daily|page=2C|accessdate=March 9, 2010}} UWA competes in the Ozark Region and has won regional championships in both the men and women's divisions. In addition, individual competitors have placed nationally in bull-riding and [[barrel racing]]. Hines brought more computers to campus and established new programs in [[psychology]] and [[forestry]]. In 1995, despite a lack of support for a name change,{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2DodAAAAIBAJ&sjid=EKYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3362,2882833&dq=university-of-west-alabama&hl=en|title=LU name change idea doesn't fly|date=February 10, 1995|work=Tuscaloosa News|accessdate=February 6, 2010}} the institution, considering that its regional educational mission was not reflected in its name (some thought that it sounded like a private school), adopted the name '''The University of West Alabama'''.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kjsdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=KKYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6362,1513965&dq=university-of-west-alabama&hl=en|title=LU Now University of West Alabama|last=Watkins|first=Ed|date=March 6, 1995|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=5A|accessdate=February 6, 2010}} Ed Roach (1998–2002) assumed the presidency in 1998 and set about integrating technology into every aspect of UWA life. He established the Technology 2000 campaign and helped establish UWA as one of the first [[wireless]] institutions in the region.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=aD4dAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gKYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4436,5395208&dq=university+of+west+alabama+goes+wireless&hl=en|title=Online and unplugged: wireless technology puts campus on cutting edge|last=Reeves|first=Steve|date=October 15, 2002|work=Tuscaloosa News|pages=1, 4A|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} Women's sports received a boost under his leadership. During this period, the UWA Softball Complex was completed. In February 2002, he stepped down from his position as president. The Board of Trustees met to choose a replacement on an interim basis from University employees David Taylor, Richard Holland, Roy Underwood, and Clemit Spruiell.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=fTwdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LKYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3506,5220702&dq=the+university+of+west+alabama+richard+holland&hl=en|title=Trustees to choose Roach's replacement|last=Reeves|first=Steve|date=February 28, 2002|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=1B|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} === Present day === [[File:UWA 175th Anniversary.jpg|right|thumb|Logo representing the University's 175th anniversary]] [[File:2009 Homecoming.JPG|left|thumb|The 2009 Homecoming court presented at halftime]] Richard Holland, an alumnus of the institution and former dean of the College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics, was selected by trustees to take over the position. Six months later, he was named the next University president by a unanimous vote.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lSMeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_6cEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6034,3401855&dq=the+university+of+west+alabama+richard+holland&hl=en|title=Holland named president of UWA|last=Reeves|first=Steve|date=September 10, 2002|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=1B|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} Holland is the first UWA graduate to serve as president. However, UWA's board of trustees placed him on paid leave and voted to not renew his contract in March 2014 after he challenged the board's review of his performance.{{Cite web |url=http://www.tuscaloosanews.com/article/20140303/NEWS/140309901/1007/news?Title=University-of-West-Alabama-board-of-trustees-places-school-president-Richard-Holland-on-administrative-leave&tc=ar |title=University of West Alabama board of trustees places school president Richard Holland on administrative leave |author=Ed Enoch |publisher=[[The Tuscaloosa News]] |date=March 3, 2014 |accessdate=March 4, 2014}} Enrollment continues to grow each year. After hovering around the 2,000 mark for a few years, that number was exceeded in the fall of 2002. In 2005, enrollment reached the 3,000 mark for the first time with a combined 3,090 students on campus and online.{{cite news|url=http://www.wtok.com/news/headlines/1850812.html|title=UWA historic enrollment|last=Williams|first=Andrea|date=September 14, 2005|work=WTOK News Center 11|accessdate=March 7, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110718123336/http://www.wtok.com/news/headlines/1850812.html|archive-date=July 18, 2011|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} That number continued to rise the following year to 3,633 and topped 4,000 in 2007 when 4,186 students were enrolled. When the fall semester rolled around, the University was just shy of the 5,000 mark at 4,888. In 2009, a higher education center was added in neighboring [[Demopolis, Alabama|Demopolis]].{{cite news|url=http://www.demopolistimes.com/news/2009/jun/19/uwa-good-partner-education/|title=UWA a good partner in education|date=June 19, 2009|work=Demopolis Times|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} Dr. Don C. Hines died on August 26 from cancer.{{cite news|url=http://www.uwa.edu/newsEvents/newsDetails.aspx?Channel=%2fChannels%2fAdmissions+and+Campus+Wide&WorkflowItemID=91f23dbd-0274-452d-a62e-1a82d8ff0ca6|title=UWA community remembers Hines|last=Gordon|first=Meaghan|date=August 28, 2009|publisher=''The University of West Alabama Public Relations''|accessdate=February 10, 2010}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} UWA was temporarily on probation with the [[Southern Association of Colleges and Schools]] accreditation body in 2011.{{cite web |url=http://sacscoc.org/details.asp?instid=43360 |title=University of West Alabama Accreditation Status with the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools |publisher=Southern Association of Colleges and Schools Commission on Colleges |year=2011 |accessdate=November 3, 2011}} It was removed from probation on December 5, 2011.{{cite news |title=UWA meets SACS requirements |author=Jason Cannon |url=http://www.demopolistimes.com/2011/12/06/uwa-meets-sacs-requirements/ |date=Demopolis Times |accessdate=December 7, 2011}} == Academics == The mission of the University of West Alabama is "to provide opportunities for students to pursue a quality education and assist in developing the important qualities of independent thinking, respect for the ideas of others, personal integrity and character in order to realize their quests for a philosophy of life and self-fulfillment."{{cite web|url=http://tigerpaw.uwa.edu/mission.asp|title=UWA Mission Statement |publisher=The University of West Alabama|accessdate=February 7, 2010}} UWA offers more than 60 undergraduate programs and 10 graduate programs through its academic colleges and divisions at the bachelor's, master's, educational specialist, and educational doctorate levels. They are as follows: {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} *'''College of Business''' *'''Julia Tutwiler College of Education''' *'''College of Liberal Arts''' *'''College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics''' *'''Division of Online Programs''' *'''Division of Technology''' *'''Ira D. Pruitt School of Nursing''' *'''School of Graduate Studies''' {{colend}} Degrees in each academic college and division are awarded at the Bachelor of Arts, Bachelor of Science, [[Bachelor of Business Administration]], Master's degree and [[Educational Specialist|Educational specialist]] levels. Students are awarded an [[Associate's degree]] from the Ira D. Pruitt School of Nursing. Upon graduation from the University of West Alabama, students may choose to earn a [[Bachelor's degree]] in [[nursing]] through a partnership with the [[University of Alabama]]. == Campus == The University of West Alabama is a single-campus university located in the heart of downtown [[Livingston, Alabama|Livingston]] on [[U.S. Route 11 in Alabama|U.S. Highway 11]]. The campus is on the western border of [[Alabama]]. Larger cities close by include [[Meridian, Mississippi|Meridian]] (30 minutes), [[Tuscaloosa, Alabama|Tuscaloosa]] (50 minutes), and [[Birmingham, Alabama|Birmingham]]. The small population in the city of Livingston and [[Southern hospitality]] give UWA its small-town atmosphere that many students come to appreciate. The {{convert|600|acre|km2|adj=on}} UWA campus includes nature trails, a {{convert|54|acre|m2|adj=on}} lake, and sculptures. Recent campus beautification projects have enhanced the natural beauty that can be found on campus.{{cite web|url=http://gowest.uwa.edu/location/article_4_3.html|title=UWA and the Community|publisher=UWA Admissions|date=August 1, 2009|accessdate=February 9, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100611072051/http://gowest.uwa.edu/location/article_4_3.html|archive-date=June 11, 2010|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} === Facilities === [[File:UWA-Bibb Graves.jpg|right|thumb|Bibb Graves Hall on the campus of the University of West Alabama]] The University of West Alabama campus includes many buildings.{{cite web|url=http://www.uwa.edu/Media/Website%20Resources/catalog/general.pdf|title=Undergraduate Catalog 2009–2010|pages=9–10|publisher=The University of West Alabama Printing Department|date=June 1, 2009|accessdate=February 9, 2010}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Some are used for academic purposes, while others serve different needs. These facilities include the following: *'''Bibb Graves Hall''' houses the College of Natural Sciences and Mathematics, School of Graduate Studies, and Division of Online Programs. In addition to the University's main auditorium, classrooms, laboratories, and faculty offices are located inside. *'''Brock Hall''' contains the Ira D. Pruitt Division of Nursing as well as the Housing Office and Upward Bound Program. *'''Lyon Hall''' hosts the Julia Tutwiler College of Education. *'''Lucille Foust Hall''' is made up of offices and classrooms for the art department and band hall. Offices for the Athletic Department and Student Success Center also reside in this building. *'''Pruitt Hall''' is the location of the Physical Education and Athletic Training Department. There are a number of classrooms, practice and dressing rooms, and studios. The building is also the primary location for the campus music program. *The '''Guy Hunt Technical Education Complex''' and '''Hunt Annex''' is used for the Division of Technology. Both contain instructional spaces and shop facilities as well as classrooms and laboratories. The Early Intervention Center can be found at this building. *The '''Julia Tutwiler Library''' holds the University's books and periodicals in addition to many other resources. Conference rooms and a computer laboratory exist on the first floor. The second floor contains a large collection of books as well as lounge areas and study areas for students. *'''Lurleen Burns Wallace Hall''' provides instruction for a number of subject areas on campus. These range from English and foreign languages, history, and social sciences to speech and theatre. The College of Business and College of Liberal Arts call this building their home. Other buildings located on campus are listed below: *'''The Bell Conference Center''' can be found in the middle of campus and is host to convocations, luncheons, and special events. *'''Kelly Hester Land Hall''' contains the Division of Educational Research and Department of Continuing Education. The Center for the Study of the Black Belt is located inside this building as well. *'''Moon Hall''' holds a warehouse area for the Physical Plant Department. *'''The President's Home''' is a residence for the University President and his family. *The '''George C. Wallace Student Union Building''' (known as the '''''SUB''''') provides a number of student activities and recreation. A student weight room is located downstairs next to the campus pool and racketball courts. There is a lounge area, computer lab, conference room, and activity area upstairs. Also located in the building are the University Bookstore and Campus Post Office. *'''Webb Hall''' is the primary home of the central administrative offices on campus. *'''Young Hall''' (affectionately referred to as '''''the CAF''''') houses the campus dining facility and kitchens. A private dining room is used for campus-sponsored special events. *'''Alfa Environmental Hall''' contains the Alabama Onsite Wastewater Training Center. *'''The Armory''', a retired part of a local army base, contains the University's Campus Police and UWA Campus School. The school offers classrooms and a play area for three- and four-year-olds. Recently, a kindergarten program was added for school-age children. == Student life == === Demographics === The University of West Alabama has a diverse student population. As of the fall semester of 2008, the University has a total enrollment of 4,888 undergraduate and [[graduate student|graduate]] students. 63% of the total enrollment is female, while males make up the remaining 37%. Most students who attend UWA are from [[Alabama]], while others come from all over [[Earth|the world]].{{cite news|url=http://www.uwa.edu/oie/factbook/demographics/2008.aspx|title=Fall 2008 Student Body Demographics|publisher=The University of West Alabama|accessdate=February 11, 2010}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} 48% are [[Caucasian race|Caucasian]], 50% are [[minorities]], and the final 2% are international students.{{cite news|url=http://www.uwa.edu/generalinformation/quickfacts.aspx|title=Quick Facts from 2008–2009 Data|publisher=The University of West Alabama|accessdate=February 11, 2010}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} 38% of the students (both campus and online) make up the Julia Tutwiler College of Education. The remaining three colleges are all in close proximity to each other. The Division of Nursing stakes claim to the final 4% of the student population.{{cite news|url=http://www.uwa.edu/oie/factbook/studenttotals/2008.aspx|title=Student Totals by College|publisher=The University of West Alabama|accessdate=February 11, 2010}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In figures from 2008, the University has a faculty of 97. The numbers are about even, as 48.5% of the total faculty are men; the remaining 51.5% are women. 77% of the faculty possess [[terminal degree]]s. Two-thirds hold the rank of associate professor or higher. 37 faculty members were tenured with 40 on tenure track. 16% are members of minority groups. The student-teacher ratio on campus is 18:1.{{cite news|url=http://www.uwa.edu/oie/factbook/quickfacts/faculty.aspx|title=Faculty 2008 Quick Facts|publisher=The University of West Alabama|accessdate=February 11, 2010}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} === Housing life === Although the University does not require students to live on campus, UWA strongly encourages students to live in a residence hall their freshman and sophomore years. Research has shown that students who live on campus are much more likely to graduate from college than students who live off-campus. Students who receive a Trustee Scholarship from the University or participate in certain activities such as varsity-level athletics may be required to live on campus. Three buildings make up the traditional residence halls on the University campus. These are Spieth Hall, Selden Hall and Sisk Hall. Most students who attend the University reside in these residence halls. Three buildings make up the residential scholar communities on the University campus. These are Reed Hall, Stickney Hall and Hoover Apartments. First-year freshmen on a Trustee Scholarship are given priority to stay in Reed Hall. Sophomore students and above are given preferences in Stickney Hall, Hoover Apartments, and Patterson Apartments.{{cite news|url=http://www.uwa.edu/studentlife/housing/where.aspx|title=Housing and Residential Life|publisher=The University of West Alabama|accessdate=February 7, 2010}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} === Media and entertainment === [[File:Paragon Yearbooks.JPG|right|thumb|''The Paragon'' 2006–2009 copies]] The official student newspaper is ''Muse''. It is published weekly by students and advised by members of the UWA faculty. First published in 1940, the newspaper was called ''Livingston Life'' until 1995 when it changed to ''The Life''. This lasted until 2010, when ''The Life'' was rebranded into ''Muse''. Students also produce the official University of West Alabama yearbook called ''The Paragon''. Much like the campus newspaper, the yearbook is published by a student staff with a faculty advisor. It is unknown when the first yearbook was published. In addition, ''The Sucarnochee Review'' is a creative-writing and art journal published by the University's Department of Languages and Literature. The journal got its start on campus in the 1970s. Students serve as staff members for the journal under a faculty advisor and faculty advisory board. Also on campus, the University's theatre program presents two full-length plays each year. These are performed by members of the student body with an advisor during the fall and spring [[semester]]s. Finally, the University of West Alabama provides educational video services to the community through Studio 96. The students produce a weekly local news broadcast named TIGER PAUSE which is broadcast on a YouTube channel named studio96productions. == Greek life == ===Greek life=== The University of West Alabama's Greek system comprises 8 fraternities and 6 sororities. Fraternities and sororities take part in a number of philanthropic programs and provide social opportunities for students. Formal rush takes place at the start of every fall semester.{{cite news|url=http://www.uwa.edu/greek_life.aspx|title=Greek Life|publisher=The University of West Alabama|accessdate=October 6, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121114003531/http://www.uwa.edu/greek_life.aspx|archive-date=November 14, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} ===IFC fraternities=== *[[Delta Chi]] *[[Sigma Pi]] *[[Tau Kappa Epsilon]] ===Panhellenic sororities=== *[[Alpha Sigma Alpha]] *[[Alpha Sigma Tau]] *[[Phi Mu]] ===National Pan–Hellenic Organizations=== ---Sororities--- *[[Alpha Kappa Alpha]] *[[Delta Sigma Theta]] *[[Zeta Phi Beta]] *[[Sigma Gamma Rho]] ---Fraternities--- *[[Alpha Phi Alpha]] *[[Kappa Alpha Psi]] *[[Phi Beta Sigma]] *[[Omega Psi Phi]] === Student organizations === The University of West Alabama has multiple student organizations and honor societies on its campus for students to join. With over 50 of these on campus, students can choose from a variety to become a member of. There are athletic support groups, governing and programming organizations, musical, religious, and special interest organizations just to name a few. UWA also has quite a number of honor societies in addition to these social organizations.{{cite news|url=http://www.uwa.edu/studentLife/organizations.aspx|title=Student Organizations|publisher=The University of West Alabama|accessdate=February 7, 2010}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} == Athletics and traditions == {{Main|West Alabama Tigers}} [[File:Luie the Tiger.jpg|thumb|110px|right|Luie the Tiger]] The University of West Alabama features 12 sports teams (13 beginning in 2011–2012 with the addition of women's soccer). Both the male and female athletic teams are called the '''West Alabama Tigers'''. Ten of the twelve teams participate in the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]'s [[NCAA Division II|Division II]] as a member of the [[Gulf South Conference]] East Division. Men's and women's rodeo compete in the Ozark Region of the [[National Intercollegiate Rodeo Association]]. The NCAA's [[NCAA Division II|Division II]] sports at the University of West Alabama include baseball, basketball, cross country, [[American football|football]], golf, outdoor track, soccer, and tennis for men; basketball, cross country, golf, soccer, [[softball]], tennis, outdoor track, and volleyball for women. The University's official mascot is Luie the Tiger. As an [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]] member in 1971, the football team won the school's only national championship in any sport.{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5v0cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=IJwEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5660,2766987&dq=livingston+university+football&hl=en|title=Happy Tigers win big one|last=Trimm|first=Mickey|date=December 12, 1971|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=1B|accessdate=March 7, 2010}} In 1992, the baseball team made history, advancing to their only [[NCAA Division II Baseball Championship|Division II College World Series]]. Their chances for the school's first baseball national championship ended in tough luck as they dropped two of three games.{{cite web|url=http://www.uwaathletics.com/sports/2010/2/2/BB_0202105949.aspx?path=baseball|title=2010 UWA Baseball Media Guide|pages=41–45|publisher=UWA Athletic Department|date=January 1, 2010|accessdate=February 8, 2010}} In 1997, the Tiger softball program made its only trip to the national tournament and posted a 1–2 record on the campus of [[Barry University]].{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=UDsdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BaYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6786,1024906&dq=livingston+university+softball&hl=en|title=UWA softball selected to play in regionals|date=May 6, 1997|work=Tuscaloosa News|page=3C|accessdate=February 25, 2010}} The men's and women's basketball teams have each made two appearances in the NCAA Tournament.{{cite web|url=http://issuu.com/uwa_athletics/docs/2009-10_uwa_men_s_basketball_media_guide|title=2009–2010 West Alabama Men's Basketball Media Guide|page=51|publisher=UWA Athletic Department|date=August 1, 2009|accessdate=February 7, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://issuu.com/uwa_athletics/docs/media_guide_print|title=2009–10 Women's Basketball Media Guide|pages=62|publisher=UWA Athletic Department|date=August 1, 2009|accessdate=February 8, 2010}} The football team made its first trip to the NCAA Division II Championship since 1975 during the 2009 season. They upset [[Albany State University|Albany State]] in the first round{{cite news|url=http://www.ncaafootball.com/index.php?s=&url_channel_id=35&url_subchannel_id=&url_article_id=18516&change_well_id=2=en |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180315134146/http://www.ncaafootball.com/index.php?s=&url_channel_id=35&url_subchannel_id=&url_article_id=18516&change_well_id=2=en |dead-url=yes |archive-date=March 15, 2018 |title=UWA Advances to 2nd round of NCAA Division II Championship |date=November 14, 2009 |publisher=UWA Athletics |accessdate=February 6, 2010 }} before ultimately falling to Carson-Newman in the second round. The 2011 team went 8-4, beat DI foe [[Georgia State University|Georgia State]], and qualified for the NCAA DII tournament. The 2012 team went undefeated in Gulf South play (5-0) to claim the conference title. UWA defeated [[Miles College]] 41-7 in round one of the playoffs. The team lost at eventual national champion [[Valdosta State Blazers football|Valdosta State]] 49-21 in the second round. UWA finished 9-4. In 2017, the men's soccer team advanced to the Sweet 16 of the NCAA Division II tournament losing to Lynn University 1-0. In addition to varsity sports, the University offers a wide variety of [[intramural sport]]s programs. Recently, an 18-hole [[disc golf]] course was added to the University campus. == Notable people == * [[Jeff Branson (baseball player)|Jeff Branson]], retired [[Major League Baseball]] infielder * [[Andrew Killgore]], former U.S. Ambassador to [[Qatar]] * [[Charles Martin (football player)|Charles Martin]], retired [[National Football League]] defensive tackle * [[Buddy Nix]], General Manager of the [[Buffalo Bills]] * [[Stelio Savante]], Hollywood actor * [[Johnny Shepherd]], [[Canadian Football League]] award winner, NFL and Arena football player * [[Lois Wilson (actress)|Lois Wilson]], silent movie star and [[Miss Alabama]] in the 1920s * [[The Usos|Jonathan Solofa Fatu Jr and Joshua Samuel Fatu]], wrestlers in the WWE under the moniker The Usos. * [[Ken Hutcherson]], NFL linebacker; senior pastor at Antioch Bible Church in Kirkland, Washington; author and Christian commentator * [[Deon Lacey]], [[Canadian Football League]] * [[Otha Foster]], [[Canadian Football League]] * [[Seth Roberts (American football)]], NFL wide receiver * [[Kendrick Office]], NFL defensive end * [[Malcolm Butler]], NFL cornerback for the [[Tennessee Titans]] * [[Tyreek Hill]], NFL wide receiver and return specialist for the [[Kansas City Chiefs]] * [[Mickey Andrews]], Head Coach, Livingston University (1970–1972), 1971 National Championship Team ==Alumni== The UWA National Alumni Association is the official [[alumni association]] of the University of West Alabama. Formed in 1910, the UWA National Alumni Association currently has 16 chapters. It is headquartered at the University of West Alabama's Webb Hall. The association works to assist the University of West Alabama in achieving its goals by serving as a catalyst for building alumni relationships, raising scholarship money for students, assisting with recruitment of potential students, and organizing programs and events such as homecoming.{{cite web|url=http://alumni.uwa.edu/|title=UWA National Alumni Association|date=January 1, 2005|publisher=The University of West Alabama|accessdate=February 7, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091230162600/http://alumni.uwa.edu/|archive-date=December 30, 2009|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == *[http://www.uwa.edu/ Official website] *[http://www.uwaathletics.com/ Official Athletics website] {{Gulf South Conference navbox}} {{Public colleges and universities in Alabama}} {{Coord|32.590|-88.186|display=title}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:West Alabama, University Of}} [[Category:University of West Alabama| ]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Alabama]] [[Category:Public universities]] [[Category:Universities and colleges accredited by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1835]] [[Category:Education in Sumter County, Alabama]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Sumter County, Alabama]] [[Category:1835 establishments in Alabama]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} A '''Vocational Education Committee''' ('''VEC''') ({{lang-ga|Coiste Gairmoideachais}}) was a [[statute|statutory]] local education body in the [[Republic of Ireland]] that administered some secondary education, most adult education and a very small amount of primary education in the state. Before 1992 VECs had authority over the [[Dublin Institute of Technology]] and the [[Regional Technical College]]s. They existed from 1930 to 2013, when they were replaced by [[Education and Training Board]]s.<ref>{{cite news|title=Education and Training Boards replace VECs to save €2m a year|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/ireland/education-and-training-boards-replace-vecs-to-save-2m-a-year-599013.html|accessdate=2 July 2013|newspaper=[[Irish Examiner]]|date=1 July 2013}}</ref>
==Establishment== VECs were originally created by the Vocational Education Act 1930, as successors to the Technical Instruction Committees established by the Agriculture and Technical Instruction (Ireland) Act 1899. The original purpose of the committees was to administer continuation and technical education for 14- to 16-year-olds. Continuation education was defined as ''"general and practical training in preparation for employment in trades"'', while technical education was described as ''"pertaining to trades, manufacturers, commerce and other industrial pursuits"''. To this end the VECs were charged with the duty of setting up and maintaining [[vocational school]]s.<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1930_29.html Vocational Education Act, 1930, accessed 20 October 2007]</ref>
==Duties== Over time the duties of VECs increased, in particular in the area of adult education. These included:
''Post-primary (secondary) education'' *Vocational Schools *Community Colleges
''Further and adult education'' *Post-Leaving Certificate courses (PLCs) *Youthreach Services *Vocational Training Opportunities Scheme (VTOS) *Community Education<ref>[http://www.corkvec.ie/about/ ''What are VECs?'', (Cork VEC), visited 20 October 2007]</ref> *Adult Literacy and Basic Education *Back To Education Initiative (BTEI) *Adult Refugee Programme (ARP)
VECs also administered maintenance grants and bursaries for third-level education until 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Quick guide to the SUSI grant process|url=http://www.studentfinance.ie/mp9544/quick-guide-to-the-susi-grant-process/index.html|work=studentfinance.ie|accessdate=2 July 2013}}</ref>
In September 2008, County Dublin VEC opened the first Community [[National school (Ireland)|National School]], in [[Porterstown]], Dublin 15. This marked the first time a VEC had become involved in primary school education.<ref>[http://www.codubvec.ie/index.cfm/go/news_one/news_key/266]</ref>
==Organisation== VECs were originally established in each [[administrative county]] and [[county borough]] in the then [[Irish Free State]]. In addition, a VEC was formed in those [[municipal borough]]s and [[Urban district (Great Britain and Ireland)|urban district]]s which had a separate Technical Instruction Committee under the 1899 legislation (namely [[Bray, County Wicklow|Bray]], [[Drogheda]], [[Sligo]], [[Tralee]] and [[Wexford]]) and in the newly created [[Corporation of Dún Laoghaire|Borough of Dún Laoghaire]].
The number of VECs was reduced to the final number of thirty-three when five town committees were amalgamated with the adjacent county committees, leaving Dún Laoghaire as the only VEC area not consisting of a city or county.
===Committees=== Each Vocational Education Committee was elected by the county, borough or urban district council and consisted partly of councillors and partly of persons with an ''"interest and experience in education"'' and who could be recommended by bodies ''"interested in manufacture or trades"''.
The Vocational Education (Amendment) Act 2001 changed the composition of the committees, and parents of students under 18 and members of the staff were also entitled to elect committee members. Members could also be appointed to represent the interests of students, voluntary organisations, community organisations, [[Irish language]] interests and business.<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/2001/en/act/pub/0023/index.html Vocational Education (Amendment) Act 2001, accessed 20 October 2007]</ref>
==List of Vocational Education Committees 1997–2013== {| class="wikitable" ! VEC ! Notes |- |County Carlow || |- |County Cavan || |- |County Clare || |- |City of Cork || |- |County Cork || |- |County Donegal || |- |City of Dublin || |- |County Dublin |Covered [[Fingal]], [[South Dublin]] and part of [[Dún Laoghaire–Rathdown]] |- |Dún Laoghaire |Part of Dún Laoghaire–Rathdown (the former borough of Dún Laoghaire) |- |City of Galway || |- |County Galway || |- | Kerry Education Service (County Kerry VEC) || Absorbed Town of Tralee VEC 1997<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1997/en/si/0089.html S.I. No. 89/1997 — Vocational Education (Urban District of Tralee Vocational Education Area and County Kerry Vocational Education Area) Amalgamation Order, 1997]</ref> |- |County Kildare || |- |County Kilkenny || |- |County Laois || |- |County Leitrim || |- |City of Limerick || |- |County Limerick || |- |County Longford || |- |County Louth ||Absorbed Town of Drogheda VEC 1997<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1997/en/si/0090.html S.I. No. 90/1997 — Vocational Education (Borough of Drogheda Vocational Education Area and County Louth Vocational Education Area) Amalgamation Order, 1997, accessed 20 October 2007]</ref> |- |County Mayo || |- |County Meath || |- |County Monaghan || |- |County Offaly || |- |County Roscommon || |- |County Sligo ||Absorbed Town of Sligo VEC 1997<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1997/en/si/0092.html S.I. No. 92/1997 — Vocational Education (Borough of Sligo Vocational Education Area and County Sligo Vocational Education Area) Amalgamation Order, 1997, accessed 20 October 2007]</ref> |- ||North Tipperary || |- ||South Tipperary || |- |City of Waterford || |- |County Waterford || |- |County Westmeath || |- |County Wexford || Absorbed Town of Wexford VEC 1997<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1997/en/si/0088.html S.I. No. 88/1997 — Vocational Education (Borough of Wexford Vocational Education Area and County Wexford Vocational Education Area) Amalgamation Order, 1997, accessed 20 October 2007]</ref> |- |County Wicklow || Absorbed Town of Bray VEC 1997<ref>[http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1997/en/si/0091.html S.I. No. 91/1997 — Vocational Education (Urban District of Bray Vocational Education Area and County Wicklow Vocational Education Area) Amalgamation Order, 1997, accessed 20 October 2007]</ref> |}
==Amalgamations and abolition== In October 2010 the [[Department of Education and Skills (Ireland)|Department of Education and Skills]] announced that the number of VECs was to be reduced from 33 to 16 by amalgamation<ref>{{cite news |title=Cabinet agrees to cut number of VECs |newspaper=[[Irish Times]] |date=13 October 2010 |url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2010/1013/1224280973224.html |author=Seán Flynn }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.education.ie/home/home.jsp?maincat=&pcategory=10861&ecategory=10876&sectionpage=12251&language=EN&link=link001&page=1&doc=51053 |title=Tánaiste announces restructuring of Vocational Education Committees (VECs) – Number of VECs reduced from 33 to 16 |date=12 October 2010 |work=Press Releases |publisher=[[Department of Education and Skills (Ireland)]] |accessdate=14 October 2010}}</ref> In 2011 the new government confirmed that scale of reduction but revised the scheme of amalgamations<ref>[http://www.education.ie/home/home.jsp?maincat=&pcategory=10861&ecategory=10876&sectionpage=12251&language=EN&link=link001&page=1&doc=54260 29 June 2011 – Minister for Education and Skills announces revised mergers of Vocational Education Committees (VECs)]</ref> It subsequently announced the establishment of SOLAS, a new steering and funding agency to cover the further education provision of the VECs, which also absorbed the training activities formerly carried out by [[FÁS]].<ref>[http://www.education.ie/home/home.jsp?maincat=&pcategory=10861&ecategory=10876&sectionpage=12251&language=EN&link=link001&page=1&doc=54506 27 July 2011 – New further education and training authority, SOLAS, launched by Minister Quinn- Government agrees to wind down FÁS]</ref>
Under the terms of the Education and Training Boards Act 2013 the VECS were dissolved, being replaced by 16 Education and Training Boards (ETBs) on 1 July 2013:<ref>{{cite web|title=Education and Training Boards Act 2013|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/2013/en/act/pub/0011/print.html#sched3|work=Irish Statute Book|accessdate=2 July 2013}}</ref>
# County Dublin VEC and Dún Laoghaire VEC replaced by Dublin & Dún Laoghaire ETB # City of Dublin VEC replaced by City of Dublin ETB # City of Galway VEC, County Galway VEC and County Roscommon VEC replaced by Galway & Roscommmon ETB # County Cork VEC and City of Cork VEC replaced by Cork ETB # County Kerry VEC replaced by Kerry ETB # City of Limerick VEC, County Limerick VEC and County Clare VEC replaced by Limerick & Clare ETB # City of Waterford VEC, County Waterford VEC and County Wexford VEC replaced by Waterford & Wexford ETB # North Tipperary VEC and South Tipperary VEC replaced by Tipperary ETB # County Donegal VEC replaced by Donegal ETB # County Kildare VEC and County Wicklow VEC replaced by Kildare & Wicklow ETB # County Mayo VEC, County Sligo VEC and County Leitrim VEC replaced by Mayo, Sligo & Leitrim ETB # County Cavan VEC and County Monaghan VEC replaced by Cavan & Monaghan ETB # County Laois VEC and County Offaly VEC replaced by Laois & Offaly ETB # County Carlow VEC and County Kilkenny VEC replaced by Kilkenny & Carlow ETB # County Longford VEC and County Westmeath VEC replaced by Longford & Westmeath ETB # County Meath VEC and County Louth VEC replaced by Louth & Meath ETB
==External links== * [http://www.ivea.ie Irish Vocational Education Association]
==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
[[Category:Education in the Republic of Ireland]] [[Category:Secondary education in Ireland]]

revision.text:
The '''Whidden Lectures''' are a lecture series at [[McMaster University]], founded in 1954 by [[E. Carey Fox]].<ref>[http://dailynews.mcmaster.ca/story.cfm?id=2037 McMaster Daily News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> They commemorate [[Howard P. Whidden]], who was Chancellor of the university from 1923 to 1941.<ref>[https://www.questia.com/PM.qst?a=o&d=9397705 Three Aspects of Stuart England<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> They were first given in 1956. Many of the lectures have been published in book form, by [[Oxford University Press]].
*1956 [[C. W. de Kiewiet]]: The Anatomy of South African Misery<ref>OUP 1957</ref> *1957 [[Vijaya Lakshmi Nehru]]: The Evolution of India<ref name="OUP 1958">OUP 1958</ref> *1958 [[Ronald Syme]]: Colonial Elites: Rome, Spain and the Americas<ref name="OUP 1958"/> *1959 [[Charles De Koninck]]: The Hollow Universe<ref>U. De Laval, 1964</ref> *1960 [[George Norman Clark]]: Three Aspects of Stuart England<ref>OUP 1960</ref> *1961 [[William Foxwell Albright]]:.New Horizons in Biblical Research<ref>OUP 1966</ref> *1962 [[J. Robert Oppenheimer]]: The Flying Trapeze: Three crises for physicists<ref>OUP 1965</ref> *1963 [[Ian Ramsey]]: Models and Mystery<ref name="OUP 1964">OUP 1964</ref> *1964 [[David Daiches]], The Paradox of Scottish Culture: the Eighteenth Century Experience<ref name="OUP 1964"/> *1965 [[William Arthur Lewis]]: Politics in West Africa<ref>George Allen & Unwin, 1965</ref> *1966 [[Anthony Blunt]]: Picasso's 'Guernica'<ref>OUP 1969</ref> *1967 [[Northrop Frye]]: The Modern Century<ref>OUP 1967</ref> *1970 [[Eric Ashby]]: Masters and Scholars;: Reflections on the rights and responsibilities of students *1973 [[Edward Togo Salmon]]: The Nemesis of Empire<ref>OUP 1974</ref> *1974 [[Richard Stockton MacNeish]] *1975 [[Noam Chomsky]]: Reflections on Language *1983 [[A. J. Ayer]]: Freedom and Morality *1986 [[John Rupert Martin]] *1988 [[Tom Stoppard]]: The Event and the Text *1993 [[Alan James Ryan]] *1997 [[Elizabeth Loftus]] *2000 [[Bruce Meyer]]: Canadian Literature and the Western Tradition *2001 [[Steven V. W. Beckwith]] Physics and Astronomy, Johns Hopkins University, "Rocket Science and Little Green Men" *2002 Cancelled *2003 [[Jean-Daniel Stanley]] Deltas Global Change Program, Smithsonian, National Museum of Natural History, Washington, DC, "World Deltas: Archeological and Environmental Perspectives" *2005 [[Donna Haraway]] Professor of the History of Consciousness, University of California, Santa Cruz, "We Have Never Been Modern" *2006 [[Brian Massumi]] Professor of Communication, Université de Montréal, "The Ideal Streak—Why Visual Representation Always Fails," "Potential Politics and the Primacy of Preemption," and "Affect and Abstraction" *2007 [[Mervyn Morris]] Poet and Professor Emeritus of Creative Writing and West Indian Literature, University of the West Indies, "Playing with the Dialect of the Tribe: West Indian Poetry" *2008 [[Mahmood Mamdani]] Professor of Government in the Departments of Anthropology and Political Science at Columbia University, "Darfur, Politics, and the War on Terror" *2009 [[Sean B. Carroll]] Professor of Molecular Biology and Genetics, University of Wisconsin, "Remarkable Creatures: Epic Adventures in the Search for the Origin of Species" and "Endless Forms Most Beautiful: Evo-Devo and an Expanding Evolutionary Synthesis" *2011 [[Sara Ahmed]] Professor of Media and Communications, Goldsmiths, University of London, "On Being Included: On Racism and Diversity in Institutional Life" and "Wilful Subjects: On the Experience of Social Dissent" *2012 [[Ray Jayawardhana]] Professor and Canada Research Chair in Observational Astrophysics, University of Toronto. "Rocks, Ice and Penguins: Searching for Clues to Planetary Origins in Antarctica" *2013 [[Jasbir Puar]] Department of Women's and Gender Studies, Rutgers University. "Ecologies of Sensation,Sensational Ecologies: Sex and Disability in the Israeli Occupation of Palestine" *2014 [[Joanna Aizenberg]] Amy Smith Berylson Professor of Materials Science in the School of Engineering and Applied Science and Professor of Chemistry and Chemical Biology, Harvard University."Stealing from Nature: Bioinspired Materials of the Future" *2016 [[Amber Miller]] Professor of Physics and Dean of Science at Columbia University. "Nature's Ultimate Time Machine: Photographing the Infant Universe", "Cosmological Observations from the Stratosphere" *2017 [[Daphne Brooks]] Professor of African American Studies, Theater Studies, and American Studies at Yale University. "The Knowles Sisters' Political Hour: Black Feminist Sonic Dissent at the End of the Third Reconstruction", "If You Should Lose Me": The Archive, the Critic, the Record Shop & the Blues Woman" *2018 [[Joanna Bryson]] Associate Professor in the Department of Computing at the University of Bath. "The Good, the Bad, and the Synthetic"

{{Infobox scientist | birth_name = William C. Wimsatt | image = Wimsatt-May-16-2012.jpg | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1941|5|27|mf=y}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[United States]] | field = [[Philosophy of Science]]
[[Philosophy of Biology]]
[[Evolutionary Biology]] | work_institutions = [[University of Chicago]]　
[[University of Minnesota]] | alma_mater = [[University of Pittsburgh]] | religion = | doctoral_advisor = | doctoral_students = | influences = [[Richard Lewontin]], [[Herbert A. Simon]] | influenced = [[Sahotra Sarkar]], [[James Griesemer]] | known_for = Robustness
[[Heuristics]]
Generative Entrenchment
[[Reductionism]]
[[Complexity]] and Organization | prizes = }} '''William C. Wimsatt''' (born May 27, 1941) is professor emeritus in the Department of Philosophy, the Committee on Conceptual and Historical Studies of Science (previously Conceptual Foundations of Science), and the Committee on Evolutionary Biology at the [[University of Chicago]].{{cite journal|last=Bechtel|first=William|author2=Werner Callebaut |author3=James R. Griesemer |author4=Jeffrey C. Schank |title=Bill Wimsatt on Multiple Ways of Getting at the Complexity of Nature|journal=Biological Theory|year=2006|volume=1|issue=2|pages=213–219|doi=10.1162/biot.2006.1.2.213|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1162/biot.2006.1.2.213}}{{cite web|url=http://philosophy.uchicago.edu/faculty/wimsatt.html|title=University of Chicago profile|accessdate=28 July 2010}} He is currently a Winton Professor of the Liberal Arts at the University of Minnesota and Residential Fellow of the Minnesota Center for Philosophy of Science.{{cite web|last=Wimsatt|first=William|title=Professor|url=http://philosophy.umn.edu/people/FacultyProfile.php?UID=wwim}} He specializes in the [[philosophy of biology]], where his areas of interest include [[reductionism]], [[heuristics]], [[emergence]], [[scientific modeling]], [[heredity]], and [[cultural evolution]].{{cite book|last=Wimsatt|first=William|title=Re-Engineering Philosophy for Limited Beings: Piecewise Approximations to Reality|year=2007|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=0674015452|pages=450|url=https://www.amazon.com/Re-Engineering-Philosophy-Limited-Beings-Approximations/dp/0674015452}} ==Biography== Wimsatt, as an undergraduate, began studying engineering physics at [[Cornell University]]. After working for a year working as a designer in industry, he turned to philosophy receiving a BA degree ''magna cum laude'' in 1965.{{cite web|last=Wimsatt|first=William|title=biography|url=http://humbleapproach.templeton.org/complexity/WilliamCWimsatt.html|publisher=John Templeton Foundation}} Wimsatt then went to the [[University of Pittsburgh]] on [[Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation]] and [[Andrew W. Mellon Foundation|Mellon Fellowships]]. to study philosophy of science and received his PhD in 1971. His thesis{{cite book|last=Wimsatt|first=William|title=Modern science and the new teleology: I - the conceptual foundations of functional analysis|year=1971|publisher=University of Pittsburgh|pages=287|url=http://pittcat.pitt.edu/cgi-bin/Pwebrecon.cgi?BBID=1020493}} consisted of a philosophical analysis of biological function. He published three papers from his dissertation: "Teleology and the Logical Structure of Function Statements",{{cite journal|last=Wimsatt|first=William|title=Teleology and the Logical Structure of Function Statements|journal=Studies in History and Philosophy of Science|date=May 1972|volume=3|issue=1|pages=1–80|doi=10.1016/0039-3681(72)90014-3|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0039368172900143}} "Complexity and Organization",{{cite journal|last=Wimsatt|first=William|title=Complexity and Organization|journal=PSA: Proceedings of the Biennial Meeting of the Philosophy of Science Association|year=1972|volume=1971,1972|pages=67–85|jstor=3698961}} and "Reductionism, levels of organization, and the mind-body problem".{{cite journal|last=Wimsatt|first=William|title=Reductionism, levels of organization, and the mind-body problem|journal=Consciousness and the Brain|year=1976|series=Plenum Press|url=http://philpapers.org/rec/WIMRLO}} From July 1969 to December 1970, he was a postdoctoral fellow in population biology with [[Richard Lewontin]] at the [[University of Chicago]], and was subsequently hired as an assistant professor of [[Philosophy]] in 1971 and promoted to full professor in 1981. In 2007, he was named the Peter H. Ritzma Professor in Philosophy and Evolutionary Biology. He has been a visiting Distinguished Professor at [[Ohio State University]], visiting Hurst Professor and a Clark-Way Harrison Distinguished Visitor at [[Washington University in St. Louis]], a fellow at the Rockefeller Foundation's Bellagio Study and Conference Center in Italy, a senior fellow at the [[Konrad Lorenz Institute for Evolution and Cognition Research]] in Vienna, Austria, Winton University Professot at the University of Minnesota, and a fellow at the Franke Humanities Institute in Chicago. He is on the scientific advisory board of the [[Land Institute]]. ===Influences=== [[Richard Lewontin]], [[Richard Levins]], [[Herbert A. Simon]], [[Stuart Kauffman]], and [[Donald T. Campbell]] are all important influences on Wimsatt's work. Some of the most important commentators on Wimsatt's writings are his students, many of whom are now working as philosophers of science and scientists, e.g. Marshall Abrams, Douglas Allchin, Irene Appelbaum, [[William Bechtel]], Stuart Glennan, [[James R. Griesemer]], Jeffry Ramsey, Sahotra Sarkar, [[Jeffrey Schank]], and Marty Sereno.{{cite web|title=Wimsatt Fest|url=http://philosophy.uchicago.edu/conferences/_files/Wimsatt%20Fest.pdf}} ===Personal=== Wimsatt is the son of the late [[William A. Wimsatt]] who was a Cornell University professor specializing in bats.{{cite journal|last=Kwiecinski|first=Gary G.|author2=Mark A. Cukierski |title=William A. Wimsatt: Dedication and biography|journal=American Journal of Anatomy|date=April 1987|volume=178|issue=4|pages=309–311|doi=10.1002/aja.1001780402|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/aja.1001780402/abstract}} He was married to Barbara Horberg on June 13, 1971.{{cite web|last=Wimsatt|first=William|title="short" Curriculum Vita|url=http://philosophy.uchicago.edu/faculty/files/wimsatt/WimsattCV.pdf}} He has one son, [[William Upski Wimsatt]], known as an author and political activist. ==Philosophy== Wimsatt's philosophical position starts with two themes: we are limited beings and the world we try to understand is complex.{{cite web|last=Richardson|first=Robert C.|title=Re-Engineering Philosophy for Limited Beings: Piecewise Approximations to Reality|url=http://ndpr.nd.edu/news/23284/?id=11965|publisher=University of Notre Dame}} The problem then is how to build a philosophical world view based on these two themes. For Wimsatt, ''robustness'' (e.g., believing that a particular apple exists because we can see it, feel it, smell it, taste it, and hear it crunch when we eat it) is fundamental for accessing what exists in the world. The more we can detect things in multiple ways, the more we are inclined to believe they exist. Closely connected to robustness are the [[heuristics]], which we use to think about the world and are foundational to his epistemology. They are rules of thumb, which can be wrong or biased but tend to work when applied to what is robust in the world.{{cite web|title=Interview with William Wimsatt|url=http://www-news.uchicago.edu/releases/07/071004.wimsatt.shtml}} For Wimsatt, questions of [[Philosophical realism|realism]] (i.e., what exists) are not separable from questions of [[epistemology]] (i.e., what we can know) and the discovery of what exists.{{cite web|last=Wimsatt|first=William|title=Video on philosophy and philosophy of biology|url=http://www-news.uchicago.edu/releases/07/video/071004.wimsatt6.mov}} This may appear circular, but it is by [[evolution]] that we have evolved multiple ways of detecting things in the world. == Awards == Wimsatt was awarded the 2013 [[David Hull]] award for outstanding contributions to Philosophy of Biology and support of students in the profession by the International Society for History Philosophy and Social Studies of Biology. ==Selected publications== * (1972). "Teleology and the Logical Structure of Function Statements." ''Studies in History and Philosophy of Science'' 3: 1-80. * (1980). "Reductionistic Research Strategies and their Biases in the Units of Selection Controversy." In ''Scientific Discovery: Case Studies'', ed. T. Nickles, pp. 213–259. * (1981). "Units of Selection and the Structure of the Multi-Level Genome." ''PSA'' 1980: 122-183. * (1986). "Developmental Constraints, Generative Entrenchment, and the Innate-Acquired Distinction." In ''Integrating Scientific Disciplines'', ed. W. Bechtel, pp. 185–208. * (1997). "Functional Organization, Functional Analogy, and Functional Inference." ''Evolution and Cognition'' 3: 2-32. * (1999). "Genes, Memes, and Cultural Heredity." ''Biology and Philosophy'' 14: 279-310 * (2007). ''Re-Engineering Philosophy for Limited Beings: Piecewise Approximations to Reality''. Cambridge: Harvard University Press. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://chronicle.uchicago.edu/071004/limited-beings.shtml Interview] *[http://philosophy.umn.edu/people/FacultyProfile.php?UID=wwim University of Minnesota, Philosophy] *[http://philosophy.uchicago.edu/faculty/wimsatt.html University of Chicago, Philosophy] {{Authority control}} {{Philosophy of science|state=uncollapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wimsatt, William}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of Pittsburgh alumni]] [[Category:University of Chicago faculty]] [[Category:University of Minnesota faculty]] [[Category:Philosophy teachers]] [[Category:American philosophers]] [[Category:Philosophers of science]] [[Category:Philosophy of biology]] [[Category:Evolutionary biologists]] [[Category:1941 births]]
